_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Custom Produce has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Custom Produce, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Custom Produce has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name               | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration        Anhydrous Ammonia                15,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP

and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



Custom Produce Sales operates a commercial cold storage for a variety of fruit and vegetables in Parlier, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(6) Rooms

(2) Precools

(1) New Repack Room

(1) Old Repack Room

(1) Shipping Dock

(1) Receiving Dock



The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.



All control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly adjacent to the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:



Machinery Room

(3) Screw compressors

(3) Oil separators

(3) Plate and frame oil coolers

(1) High pressure receiver

(1) Liquid transfer vessel

(1) Main suction accumulator

(1) Thermosyphon vessel



Condenser Area

(1) Evaporative condenser

(1) Diffusion tank



Shipping Dock

(2) Accumulators

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Receiving Dock

(2) Accumulators

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 1

(1) Accumulator

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)



Room 2

(1) Accumulator

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 3 (including Gravity Rack Coil)

(1) Accumulator

(5) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 4

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 5

(1) Accumulator

(2) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Room 6

(1) Accumulator

(3) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Ro

om 7

(1) Accumulator

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate fin)



Precool 1

(1) Accumulator

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, plate fin)



Precool 2

(1) Accumulator

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (bunker-mounted, plate fin)

Old Repack Room (Coil fed from Receiving Dock West Accumulator)

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended)



Repack Room

(1) Accumulator

(6) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



The flooded system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator mounted behind the bunker wall or on the roof. From the accumulators, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator.  From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the thermosyphon vessel and then to the high pressure receiver.



The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the ammonia diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. 



There is an ammonia detector installed inside the Refrigeration Machinery Room, Rooms 1-6, Precool 1-2, Old Repack Room, Repack Room, and Receiving and Shipping Dock. Each ammonia detector is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate an audible alarm and strobe.



An emergency control box is installed

on the west  exterior wall of the refrigeration machinery room, which contains three valves. The high and low side of the system each have a valve that would discharge to the diffusion tank. The connecting pipe between the high and low side has one equalizer valve that would equalize the system.



The ammonia refrigeration system at Custom Produce Sales consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping.  As such, the refrigeration system at Custom Produce Sales is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Custom Produce has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Custom Produce facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.  



1.4 Five Year Accident

History



Custom Produce has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Custom Produce's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Custom Produce has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Custom Produce continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Custom Produce's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related e

vents so that Custom Produce's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Custom Produce has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Custom Produce has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, Custom Produce now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Custom Produce employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Custom Produce will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
